A very simple definition I found.

Almost all the satellites that are in a polar orbit are at lower altitudes. Plus, they are often used for applications such as monitoring crops, forests and even global security.

A polar orbit travels north-south over the poles and takes approximately an hour and a half for a full rotation. As the satellite is in orbit, the Earth is rotating beneath it. As a result, a satellite can observe the entire Earth’s surface (off-nadir) in the time span of 24 hours.
https://gisgeography.com/polar-orbit-sun-synchronous-orbit/

So at the same time it will be in the same latitude every day.
It's synchronized with the sun (CLOCK)
Hmm. An easier way to think of it as it's synchronous with the clock/sun.

Not exactly our clock because there's more than exactly 24 hours a day but in general.


Here it shows a sun synchronous orbit but does not rotate with the sun.
https://marine.rutgers.edu/cool/education/class/paul/orbits2.html
So it doesn't have to match the shadow. It matches time every day same location.

At 46:20...Modern jetliners not only use GPS but also uses instrument landing system (ILS) or microwave landing system (MLS). Though not all airports have this system..This system actually guides in the plane for a landing..If the headwind,tailwind and crosswind are within the system's limits. The plane can land itself automatically and can land with virtually zero visability(if you went up and painted the windshield with opaque colour this system will still land the plane safely). I am waiting for the day when planes will be flown 100% using instruments. And seeing the progress we may see it in our lifetime.

SUN-SYNCHRONOUS ORBIT: The Earth is not a perfect sphere, thus the gravity force does not pull exactly towards the Earths center. In every point of every orbit gravity has a little deviation from this line, out of the plane of the orbit (remember that the plane of the orbit contains the orbit and the center of the Earth). This out-of-plane force makes the plane of the orbit rotate. The rotation rate depends on the orbit inclination and altitude. So, SSO's use a combination of inclination and altitude that makes the rotation rate of the orbital plane = 360 degrees/365 days. Each full day it will rotate a bit, about 1 degree, just enough that, as the Earth moves around the Sun, the Sun will be exactly over the same point of the Earth when the satellite passes. This allows for example, to take photographs at the exact same solar hour on the same location all year round. Hope this helps. You granted me a a lot of great times. Thanx a lot!
PS: if you have STK it's really easy to visualize if you plot a couple of different orbits and propagate them through the year

The idea of refueling at the moon, in orbit would be fine if you didn't have to slow down to make orbit and lock up with a fuel tanker.  Putting fuel in orbit from the moon is much easier than doing it from the earth.  The problem is how much fuel can you really make on the moon?  Is it economical, feasible and efficient?  Putting fuel into orbit that matches the speed of a ship in the lunar orbit plus the speed of the moon's orbit makes a lot of sense, but it might be even better to send that fuel ahead of the ship on the way to mars and refuel on rout so the mars ship doesn't have to slow down and then speed up again to orbit the moon, just shoot by it.  It's like that baton race, with 3 tandem runners passing the baton, as the first runner approaches the second runner, the second speeds up to get into a position that doesn't lose any velocity for the baton.    The tank could then use a small left over bit of fuel to go back to the moon and land to be refueled.  Similar to what space x is doing with it's first stage booster.  This would save fuel and speed on the way to mars.

Ok a sun synchronous orbit has a high orbital inclination such that the altitude the satellite orbits at determines its orbital period.  Divide 24 hours by the period and that tells you how many degrees apart each successive orbit has to be. The inclination keeps the orbital plane perpendicular to the Earth-Sun axis. Thus the satellite is always exposed to the sun at every point in its orbit, it follows the terminator line on earth of night vs day. This is different from a solar synchronous orbit, where the satellite orbits the sun in a position in which it remains in the same position relative to the Earth. This is done at the Earth-Sun Lagrange points and is used to observe the sun for flares, sunspots, and coronal mass ejections that are the main features of solar weather that can impact Earth, our satellites, and other spacecraft throughout the solar system.
Scott Manley gives a good explanation of sun synchronous orbits at 3:48. https://youtu.be/PZAkiXNJIqc

Best way to explain why "suicide burn" is efficient is just as a factor of time. Every second you spend in the influence of gravity requires Delta-V equal to the force of the gravity. Near earth, that's about 9.8m/s each second you spend falling. If you gradually slow down all the way to the ground, you are simply spending more time falling, so that 9.8m/s compounds more. That's it. You just want to get there as FAST as possible so that the surface is supporting you instead of your thruster. There's no inherent benefit to making one big fast burn vs. one long slow burn, in relation to any given acceleration. It's just that the slow burn keeps you airborne longer, and thus the total acceleration of gravity that you need to cancel is greater.

So the suicide burn is more efficient because and /only/ because it's just plain faster.


(EDIT: there's a secondary effect when you're in an atmosphere which is that aerodynamic drag increases with the square of speed, so the faster you're going, the more drag you have slowing you down, so letting your speed go up effectively cancels out some of gravity's effect, so... when landing on Earth you have two reasons!)

One problem with the investigation into aerospace accidents is that, even if the investigators have discovered what they believe to be the cause (or causes), they have to “rule out” all of the other conceivable potential causes before they reach a final conclusion. We REALLY want to make space flight boring (read “safe” as in “no SRD’s”, “No anomalies” & “No LOCV”). An NTSB investigation can take months, so give them a couple more months. We have another Crew Dragon available for the “Flight Abort Test” & another Dragon available for the Crew Mission. The “Pad anomaly” occurred using a previously used Crew Dragon, So, except for pad clean-up & potential scheduling conflicts, this shouldn’t effect the launch schedule that much.

Scott Manley has some good explanations of Sun synchronous orbits but I forget what videos they are in. Tldr is that they are slightly inclined, I think around 8 degrees off polar, which works out such that the Earth's slight equatorial bulge pulls on the satellite slightly unevenly, which acts to gyroscopically precess the orbit relative to Earth at about the same rate that Earth moves around the Sun. I think light pressure from the sun also factors in.

If you have a gyroscope you can test it out: try to tip the axis from vertical to horizontal and you will feel it want to rotate at a right angle to the axis of rotation

I think a good way of explaining what you were talking about using KSP is by explaining it in terms of energy.  While a vehicle is falling through the atmosphere, gravity is converting potential energy (the vehicle's height above the ground) into potential energy (the vehicles speed/velocity).  When the engines are burning, you're effectively cancelling out the kinetic energy, but you really want the vehicles overall energy to be zero.  So by burning higher up, you aren't cancelling out the potential energy.  By burning as close to the ground as possible, the potential energy is very low, as it has all been converted into kinetic energy, so you are able to counteract much more energy than by burning higher up.  They time their landing burn so that the potential energy is low enough that it will hit 0 as the velocity/speed hits 0.

Sun-synchronous orbit works because it's actually slightly retrograde and as the craft falls towards the equatorial bulge gravity pulls the orbit inclination slightly. When done correctly the craft will stay almost directly in line with the day night line.

Found this online.


A satellite in sun-synchronous orbit might ascend across the equator twelve times a day each time at approximately 15:00 mean local time. This is achieved by having the osculating orbital plane precess (rotate) approximately one degree each day with respect to the celestial sphere, eastward, to keep pace with the Earth's movement around the Sun.

The uniformity of Sun angle is achieved by tuning the inclination to the altitude of the orbit such that the extra mass near the equator causes the orbital plane of the spacecraft to precess with the desired rate: the plane of the orbit is not fixed in space relative to the distant stars, but rotates slowly about the Earth's axis. Typical sun-synchronous orbits are about 600–800 km in altitude, with periods in the 96–100 minute range, and inclinations of around 98° (i.e. slightly retrograde compared to the direction of Earth's rotation: 0° represents an equatorial orbit and 90° represents a polar orbit).

https://gisgeography.com/polar-orbit-sun-synchronous-orbit/
When a satellite has a sun-synchronous orbit, it means that it has a constant sun illumination through inclination and altitude. For sun-synchronous orbits, it passes over any given point on Earth’s surface at the same local solar time.
